problem:
The number
\[\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ\]is expressed in the form $r \, \text{cis } \theta$, where $r > 0$ and $0^\circ \le \theta < 360^\circ$.  Find $\theta$ in degrees.
solution:
First, we note that the angle measures form an arithmetic sequence whose average is $111^\circ$.

We have that
\begin{align*}
&\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ  \\
&= \frac{\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ}{\text{cis } 111^\circ} \cdot \text{cis } 111^\circ \\
&= [\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)] \text{cis } 111^\circ.
\end{align*}The terms of the sum
\[\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)\]can be paired into terms of the form $\text{cis } n^\circ + \text{cis } (-n)^\circ$, and
\begin{align*}
\text{cis } n^\circ + \text{cis } (-n)^\circ &= \cos n^\circ + i \sin n^\circ + \cos n^\circ - i \sin n^\circ \\
&= 2 \cos n^\circ,
\end{align*}which is real.  Therefore,
\[\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)\]is real.  Let
\[r = \text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ).\]Then
\[\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ = r \, \text{cis } 111^\circ,\]so $\theta = \boxed{111^\circ}$.
model_solution:
## Step 1: Identify the terms in the sum as complex numbers in trigonometric form
The given sum consists of terms in the form $\text{cis } \theta$, which represents $e^{i\theta}$ or $\cos \theta + i\sin \theta$. This means each term is a complex number on the unit circle.

## Step 2: Recognize the sum as a sum of complex numbers in trigonometric form
We need to find the sum of complex numbers $\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ$. This can be viewed as adding vectors head-to-tail in the complex plane.

## Step 3: Determine the average argument of the terms
Since the terms are in an arithmetic progression of angles, we can find the average argument. The first term is $75^\circ$, the last term is $147^\circ$, and the common difference is $8^\circ$. The average argument $\theta_{avg}$ can be calculated by taking the average of the first and last term: $\theta_{avg} = \frac{75^\circ + 147^\circ}{2} = 111^\circ$.

## Step 4: Consider the symmetry of the sum around the average argument
The terms are symmetrically distributed around the average argument $111^\circ$. This symmetry means that the sum will also lie on the same line as the average argument, because the components perpendicular to this line will cancel each other out.

## Step 5: Determine the argument of the sum
Given the symmetry around $111^\circ$, the argument of the sum will be $111^\circ$.

The final answer is: $\boxed{111}$
